{{premise}}
Given the above, is it necessarily true that "{{hypothesis}}"? {{answer_choices[0]}}, {{answer_choices[2]}}, or {{answer_choices[1]}}? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

ax.name: does_hyp_follow_from_prem

|||
{{answer_choices[label]}}

mnli.name: always/sometimes/never
mnli.jinja: Suppose it's true that {{premise}} Then, is "{{hypothesis}}" {{"always"}}, {{"sometimes"}}, or {{"never"}} true? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: based on the previous passage
mnli.jinja: {{premise}} Based on the previous passage, is it true that "{{hypothesis}}"? Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}
mnli.reference: Adapted from the BoolQ prompts in Schick & Sch√ºtze 2021.

mnli.name: justified in saying
mnli.jinja: {{premise}} Are we justified in saying that "{{hypothesis}}"? Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: GPT-3 style
mnli.jinja:
{{premise}}
Question: {{hypothesis}} True, False, or Neither? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}
mnli.reference: Same as reported in Figure G7 of the GPT-3 paper, except that there is no task identifying tokens like "anli R1: ".

mnli.name: MNLI crowdsource
mnli.jinja: {{premise}} Using only the above description and what you know about the world, "{{hypothesis}}" is definitely correct, incorrect, or inconclusive? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}
mnli.reference: Adapted from Williams et al. 2018's instructions to crowdsourcing workers.

mnli.name: does it follow that
mnli.jinja: Given that {{premise}} Does it follow that {{hypothesis}} Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: can we infer
mnli.jinja: Suppose {{premise}} Can we infer that "{{hypothesis}}"? Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: consider always/sometimes/never
mnli.jinja:
{{premise}} 

Keeping in mind the above text, consider: {{hypothesis}} Is this {{"always"}}, {{"sometimes"}}, or {{"never"}} correct? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: must be true
mnli.jinja: Given that {{premise}} Therefore, it must be true that "{{hypothesis}}"? Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: does this imply
mnli.jinja:
{{premise}} 

Question: Does this imply that "{{hypothesis}}"? Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{answer_choices[label]}}

mnli.name: claim true/false/inconclusive
mnli.jinja: {{premise}} Based on that information, is the claim: "{{hypothesis}}" {{"true"}}, {{"false"}}, or {{"inconclusive"}}? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: take the following as truth
mnli.jinja:
Take the following as truth: {{premise}}
Then the following statement: "{{hypothesis}}" is {{"true"}}, {{"false"}}, or {{"inconclusive"}}? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: should assume
mnli.jinja: Given {{premise}} Should we assume that "{{hypothesis}}" is true? Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: guaranteed true
mnli.jinja: Given {{premise}} Is it guaranteed true that "{{hypothesis}}"? Yes, no, or maybe? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

mnli.name: guaranteed/possible/impossible
mnli.jinja:
Assume it is true that {{premise}} 

Therefore, "{{hypothesis}}" is {{"guaranteed"}}, {{"possible"}}, or {{"impossible"}}? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}

qqp.name: quora
qqp.jinja: I'm an administrator on the website Quora. There are two posts, one that asks "{{question1}}" and another that asks "{{question2}}". I can merge questions if they are asking the same thing. Can I merge these two questions? ||| {{ answer_choices[label] }}
